facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 497 of 57 before Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 497 of 57. Appeal from the Judgment and decree dated October 10, 1955, of the Patna High Court, in Appeal from Original Decree No. 483 of 1947.

facts.text: Respondents brought a suit with respect to ten plots of land claiming declaration of ownership, possession by ejectment of defendants-appellants, and mesne profits.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents brought a suit with respect to ten plots of land and claimed a declaration that the property belonged to them and prayed for possession of the plots by ejectment of the defendants appellants and for mesne profits, Besides the appellants,

facts.text: Appellants took a loan from other defendants on a mortgage bond.

anchor.surface_text: after their- acqittal by the companyrt of session, the appellants took possession of the property by forcibly dispossessing the respondents. Consequently the respondents filed the suit out of which this appeal has arisen in July 1946.

facts.text: High Court dismissed appeal except as to one plot, dismissed respondents' suit for that plot.

arguments.claim: Present case is misdescription (area, khata, boundaries refer to 1060; missing zero in number); no plot 160; distinguishes cases where only boundaries/no number; rejects appellants' contention.

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that the present case is analogous to a case of misdescription. As already pointed out the area, the khata number and the boundaries all refer to plot No. 1060 and what has happened is that in writing the plot number, one zero has been missed and 1060 has become 160. It is also important to remember that there is numberplot bearing No. 160, in khata No. 97.

holdings.text: The present case is a case of misdescription only where the plot number 160 in the final decree and sale certificate is a mistake for 1060, as khata number, area, and boundaries match plot 1060, no plot 160 exists in khata 97, and identity is clear; contention of appellants fails.

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that the present case is analogous to a case of misdescription. As already pointed out the area, the khata number and the boundaries all refer to plot No. 1060 and what has happened is that in writing the plot number, one zero has been missed and 1060 has become 160. It is also important to remember that there is n

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies misdescription doctrine distinguishing disputed identity; other details (khata, area, boundaries) confirm plot 1060; analogies to Thakar Barmha and Gossain Das; distinguishes Rambhadra Naidu as no reference back to prior deed needed.

holdings.text: No subrogation of Ramzan Mian and another to 1920 mortgage rights as 1927 deed silent on prior mortgage and no money left to redeem; appellants cannot raise subrogation for them; no evidence 1927 mortgage subsisting in 1932 or appellants holding for them; contention fails.

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that there is no force in these contentions raised on behalf of the Appellants. In the first place, it is difficult to understand how the appellants can raise the question of subrogation on behalf of Ramzan Man and another. In the second place, Ramzan Mian and another could only be subrogated to the rights of the mortgagees of 1920 whose mortgage they had redeemed if there was an agreement in their mortgage that they would be so subrogated.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Subrogation requires explicit agreement or funds left in subsequent deed, absent here; lack of evidence on subsistence of 1927 mortgage at 1932 suit time; appellants lack standing to assert for non-parties; High Court finding of appellants' possession in 1935 not tied to mortgagees.

holdings.text: Appellants' contention with respect to plot 1128 similar to plot 427 and therefore fails.

anchor.surface_text: Re. Plot. No. 1128 The case of the appellants with respect to this plot is similar to the case with reference to plot 427. In the circumstances the appellants contention with respect to this plot must also fail.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct analogy to reasoning and conclusion on plot 427; no distinct facts warranting different outcome.

holdings.text: The appeal fails as no other points urged.

anchor.surface_text: As no other point was urged before us, the whole appeal fails.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Arguments confined to three plots, all rejected; affirms lower courts on remaining issues.

precedents.citation: Rambhadra Naidu v. Kadiriyasami Naicker 1 1921 L. R. 48 I.A. 155

anchor.surface_text: Rambhadra Naidu v. Kadiriyasami Naicker  1 . In that case it was held that certificates of sale are documents of title which ought number to be lightly regarded or loosely companystrued. It was further held that where upon a sale under a mortgage decree the purchaser has been given a sale certificate which plainly includes certain property and has put into possession, it is number open to the Court in a subsequent suit by  1   1921  L. R. 48 I.A. 155.

precedents.cited_proposition: certificates of sale are documents of title which ought not to be lightly regarded or loosely construed; not open to go behind sale certificate to mortgage deed where sale certificate plainly includes property and possession delivered
precedents.cited_holding: where upon a sale under a mortgage decree the purchaser has been given a sale certificate which plainly includes certain property and has put into possession, it is not open to the Court in a subsequent suit by the mortgagors representative to hold by reference back to the mortgage deed that the property in question was not sold under the decree

precedents.citation: Thakar Barmha v. Jiban Ram Marwari 2 1913 L.R. 41 I.A. 38

anchor.surface_text: He relies on Thakar Barmha v. Jiban Ram Marwari 2 . In that case what had happened was that the judgment-debtor owned a mahal in which ten annas share was mortgaged while the remainder was free from encumbrances. A creditor of his attached and put up for sale six annas  2   1913 L.R. 41 I.A. 38. share out of the mortgaged share.

precedents.case_name: Thakar Barmha v. Jiban Ram Marwari
precedents.cited_proposition: in a judicial sale only the property attached can be sold; misdescription where identity clear is mere irregularity, but doubt as to identity is not misdescription
precedents.cited_holding: a property fully identified in the schedule may be in some respects misdescribed, which would be a different case

precedents.citation: Gossain Das Kundu v. Mrittunjoy Agnan Sardar 3 1913 18 C. L. J. 541

anchor.surface_text: Gossain Das Kundu v. Mrittunjoy Agnan Sardar 3 . In that case the land sold was described by boundaries and area but the area seems to have been incorrect. It was held to be a case of misdescription of the area and the boundaries were held to prevail. We are of opinion that the present case is analogous to a case of misdescription.  3   1913  18 C. L. J. 541.

precedents.case_name: Gossain Das Kundu v. Mrittunjoy Agnan Sardar
precedents.cited_proposition: where land sold described by boundaries and area but area incorrect, it is misdescription and boundaries prevail

The concept that boundaries prevail over incorrect area or description in sale documents supports the holding's conclusion of misdescription corrected by matching boundaries, khata, and area.
The concept of boundaries prevailing over incorrect listings directly addresses whether plot 1060 is included despite the plot 160 mention, by prioritizing boundaries over descriptive errors.

Section 47 CPC, which bars separate suits challenging execution sales (as per cited precedent), supports the holding that the present case involves only misdescription not amenable to collateral challenge.

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that the present case is analogous to a case of misdescription. anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that there is no force in these contentions raised on behalf of the Appellants. In the first place, it is difficult to understand how the appellants can raise the question of subrogation on behalf of Ramzan Man and another. In the second place, Ramzan Mian and another could only be subrogated to the rights of the mortgagees of 1920 whose mortgage they had redeemed if there was an agreement in their mortgage that they would be so subrogated.

Precedent supports the argument, which invokes the same language about certificates of sale not to be lightly regarded or loosely construed.
Precedent directly grounds the concept, as its holding that certificates of sale are documents of title which ought not to be lightly regarded matches the concept description exactly.
Precedent addresses the issue by providing authority on effect of sale certificates as title documents.

Precedent Thakar Barmha v. Jiban Ram Marwari states 'in a judicial sale only the property attached can be sold; misdescription where identit...', directly establishing the concept of judicial sale limited to attached property with misdescription allowance.
Precedent on misdescription in judicial sales where identity clear from attachment supports the holding that plot 160 is a mistake for 1060 based on matching khata, area, boundaries.
Precedent on limitation to attached property and misdescription addresses the issue of inclusion of plot 1060 despite mention of 160.
